      <title>San Antonio Spurs crash out of NBA playoffs after falling to Thunder</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2016/may/12/san-antonio-spurs-oklahoma-city-thunder-nba-playoffs</link>
      <description><ul><li>Oklahoma City beat San Antonio to take series 4-2</li><li>Thunder will play Warriors in Western Conference final</li></ul><p>Kevin Durant scored 37 points, Russell Westbrook added 28, and the Oklahoma City Thunder beat the San Antonio Spurs 113-99 on Thursday night to win the Western Conference semi-final series 4-2.</p><p>Steven Adams had 15 points and 11 rebounds, and Andre Roberson added 14 points for the Thunder.</p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/sport/blog/2016/may/11/nba-playoffs-tim-duncan-san-antonio-spurs">Spurs creak as the great Tim Duncan finally appears to decline</a> </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2016/may/12/san-antonio-spurs-oklahoma-city-thunder-nba-playoffs">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>University of Dayton basketball star Steve McElvene dies at age of 20</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2016/may/12/steve-mcelvene-dead-university-of-dayton-basketball</link>
      <description><ul><li>Player had set school record for blocked shots last season</li><li>Cause of death remains unconfirmed after sudden collapse</li></ul><p>The University of Dayton center Steve McElvene has died suddenly at the age of 20, the school has confirmed. A cause of death has not yet been given. </p><p>“We are devastated at this news,” the Dayton coach Archie Miller said in a statement. “Any death is a tragedy, but for someone so young, who worked so hard to have his dreams within reach, it’s hard to put into words how painful this is. Our hearts and prayers go out to Steve’s family. My family, our team and our staff will have to pull together, not only in support of Steve’s family, but in support of each other at this terrible time.”</p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2016/may/12/nba-playoffs-golden-state-warriors-portland-trail-blazers">NBA playoffs: Warriors seal Trail Blazers series as Raptors edge Heat</a> </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2016/may/12/steve-mcelvene-dead-university-of-dayton-basketball">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Jason Day shoots record-equalling round at Players Championship</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2016/may/12/jason-day-sawgrass-players-championship-lowry-rose-spieth-willett</link>
      <description>• Shane Lowry and Justin Rose two behind leader at Sawgrass<br />• Jordan Spieth level-par 72, Danny Willett signs for 70<p>The angst Jordan Spieth suffered by virtue of closing his opening round at the Players Championship with a seven, the one number that may bring him out in a cold sweat, surely intensified with a glance towards one of the his playing partners. Jason Day, who has succeeded Spieth as the world No1, endorsed his status once more with a course record-equalling 63. Day had birdie putts at all 18 holes.</p><p>As Day tapped in for birdie at the 9th, their 18th, Spieth was about to three putt for a double bogey. Spieth’s frustration at a 72 on a day of generally excellent scoring was compounded by that seven; the same scorecard aberration that fatally undermined his hopes of defending the Masters, <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2016/apr/11/danny-willett-masterrs-2016-jordan-spieth-lee-westood" title="">owing to a capitulation at Augusta National’s 12th hole</a>. Spieth later insisted his Thursday score did not appropriately represent his performance. “I really only had two bad swings today,” he said. “I’m hitting the ball great.”</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2016/may/12/jason-day-sawgrass-players-championship-lowry-rose-spieth-willett">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Serena Williams falls ill after eating dog food ... then wins at Italian Open</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2016/may/12/serena-williams-dog-food-italian-open</link>
      <description><ul><li>World No1 samples dish meant for her pet dog Chip</li><li>Goes on to beat Christian McHale in third round in Rome</li></ul><p>The benefits of special diets for athletes have been well documented, but Serena Williams may have taken things too far on Wednesday when she decided to sample her pet dog’s dinner.</p><p>Williams is playing in the Italian Open, and her hotel had prepared a special menu for her Yorkshire terrier, Chip, including a tempting salmon and rice dish. The world No1 sampled some of it, <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=IRrze_N9IpI">telling fans on Snapchat</a>: “I ate a spoonful. Don’t judge me.”</p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/sport/blog/2016/may/12/roger-federer-french-open-back-injury">Roger Federer finds time catching up with him as French Open decision awaits | Kevin Mitchell</a> </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2016/may/12/serena-williams-dog-food-italian-open">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Columbus trade Kei Kamara to New England after penalty argument</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/may/12/columbus-crew-kei-kamara-trade-new-england-mls-penalty-kick</link>
      <description><ul><li>Kamara’s transfer comes days after penalty spat with Federico Higuain<br></li><li>Revs GM Michael Burns says: ‘Kei is a proven goalscorer in MLS’<br></li></ul><p>Less than a week after a very public spat with his team-mate over who should take a penalty kick, Columbus Crew have agreed to trade Kei Kamara, last season’s leading goalscorer, to New England Revolution for a record fee. The move was finalised just before the end of the primary transfer window.</p><p>The move represents a coup for Revolution – Kamara matched Sebastian Giovinco’s regular-season tally of 22 goals last season to win the Golden Boot – but suggests Columbus were deeply troubled <a href="http://Kamara argues with Federico Higuain">by Kamara’s disagreement with Federico Higuain</a> during last week’s game against Montreal.</p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/2014/oct/14/kei-kamara-ebola-sierra-leone-wolves">Sierra Leone’s Kei Kamara: I missed out on Wolves move due to Ebola outbreak</a> </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/may/12/columbus-crew-kei-kamara-trade-new-england-mls-penalty-kick">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>NBA playoffs: Warriors seal Trail Blazers series as Raptors edge Heat</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2016/may/12/nba-playoffs-golden-state-warriors-portland-trail-blazers</link>
      <description><ul><li>Stephen Curry and Klay Thompson star in Golden State win</li><li>DeMar DeRozan’s 34 points give Toronto 3-2 lead in Miami series</li></ul><p>Golden State booked their passage to the NBA Western Conference finals for a second straight year by beating Portland 125-121 on Wednesday, <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/sport/blog/2016/may/10/stephen-curry-unanimous-nba-mvp-golden-state-warriors">with newly crowned league MVP Stephen Curry</a> hitting the sealing three-pointer to complete a 4-1 series victory.</p><p lang="en" dir="ltr">Curry was clutch late in the Game 5 win! <a href="https://twitter.com/hashtag/KiaMVP?src=hash">#KiaMVP</a> <a href="https://t.co/tTzK9ltYFV">https://t.co/tTzK9ltYFV</a></p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/sport/blog/2016/may/11/nba-playoffs-tim-duncan-san-antonio-spurs">Spurs creak as the great Tim Duncan finally appears to decline</a> </p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/sport/blog/2016/may/10/stephen-curry-unanimous-nba-mvp-golden-state-warriors">NBA MVP Stephen Curry isn't a 'system player' – he is the system</a> </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2016/may/12/nba-playoffs-golden-state-warriors-portland-trail-blazers">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Will the Gronkowskis or Currys replace the Mannings as America's sports family?</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/sport/blog/2016/may/12/mannings-most-dominant-american-sports-family</link>
      <description><p>With the retirement of Peyton, the Mannings’ athletic dominance has ended. There are plenty of candidates to fill the void though</p><p>More than three months have passed since Peyton Manning ended his career and Denver’s search for his replacement has been an ongoing story. After Brock Osweiler went to the Texans, the Broncos s<a href="http://espn.go.com/nfl/story/_/id/14951086/denver-broncos-trade-quarterback-mark-sanchez">igned Mark Sanchez</a>, reportedly kicked the tires on Colin Kaepernick, Ryan Fitzpatrick and Sam Bradford, and <a href="http://www.cbssports.com/nfl/eye-on-football/25583365/emmanuel-sanders-tells-paxton-lynch-hes-demaryius-thomas">drafted Paxton Lynch</a>. </p><p>Yet while the Broncos have temporary patched their QB hole with Sanchez and hope to have plugged for the long-term with Lynch, a large and important void remains with an impact stretching far beyond Denver: who is American sport’s reigning power family now? </p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/sport/blog/2016/feb/23/rob-gronkowskis-party-ship-booze-fuelled-nightmare-of-nfl-unifier">Rob Gronkowski's party ship: booze fuelled nightmare or NFL unifier? | DJ Gallo</a> </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/sport/blog/2016/may/12/mannings-most-dominant-american-sports-family">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Richard Linklater on Everybody Wants Some!!: 'Directing is like being a coach' – video interview</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/film/video/2016/may/12/richard-linklater-everybody-wants-some-video-interview</link>
      <description><p>Linklater’s followup to Boyhood is an 80s-set college comedy about a bunch of guys on baseball scholarships. Here he explains what sports meant to him as a teenager, and how he never meant it to be pitched as a sequel to Dazed and Confused.</p><p>Everybody Wants Some!! is released on13 May in the UK</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/video/2016/may/12/richard-linklater-everybody-wants-some-video-interview">Continue reading...</a></description>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/film/everybody-wants-some--">Everybody Wants Some!!</category>

    <item>
      <title>Why MLS clubs should steer clear of John Terry | Graham Ruthven</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/may/12/mls-top-clubs-steer-clear-john-terry</link>
      <description><p>The Chelsea captain is past his best, would cost lots in salary, and do little to dispel the notion of MLS as a retirement home for Europe’s faded stars</p><p>Perhaps John Terry’s American charm offensive started with some words of praise for Chris Wondolowski. Four years ago the Chelsea defender went out of his way to compliment the San Jose striker on his movement throughout the 2012 MLS All-Star game, which Chelsea lost 3-2. Maybe in that moment the former England captain began to think of a life for himself Stateside.</p><p>OK, so Terry probably wasn’t that cynical in his acclaim of Wondolowski, even if his remarks went against the grain of his somewhat toxic caricature. His comments were most likely off the cuff, and maybe even entirely sincere, given the manner in which Wondo so easily lost Terry as he turned home a Thierry Henry cross. With the game played four years ago, the Chelsea man probably wasn’t thinking about a Major League Soccer move just yet.</p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/may/11/john-terry-meeting-chelsea-career-over">John Terry to be told by club that Chelsea career is over</a> </p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/blog/2016/may/09/columbus-crew-penalty-mls-news-toronto-sounders">Clint Dempsey learns to love again and Crew fall apart over penalty</a> </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/may/12/mls-top-clubs-steer-clear-john-terry">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Max Scherzer ties MLB strikeout record as Nationals' momentum builds</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/sport/blog/2016/may/11/max-scherzer-mlb-strikeout-record-washington-nationals</link>
      <description><p>Between a major league record and a new $175m seven-year deal, there’s been plenty of drama at the Nats this week. Plus, Bartolo Colón is a natural, the Dodgers and the DL, Bryce Harper gets a spanking and more</p><p>Max Scherzer was approaching a record and the Washington Nationals manager Dusty Baker had a decision to make: balance the rare opportunity to make history against the danger of keeping his hurler on the hill with a high pitch count, never mind trying to win a tight ballgame during a losing stretch. </p><p lang="en" dir="ltr">Count 'em, twenty. <a href="https://t.co/uiGqQX8104">https://t.co/uiGqQX8104</a>‌<a href="https://t.co/XnkYika5Ie">https://t.co/XnkYika5Ie</a></p><p lang="en" dir="ltr">19 pitchers have thrown 80% Ks in complete game. My fave: Greg Maddux, threw 63 strikes in 76 pitches against Cubs. <a href="https://t.co/GEh3OyOJob">https://t.co/GEh3OyOJob</a></p><p>I just wish he would get to the point where he doesn’t put so many high demands on himself. That he just goes out and has a little more fun. That may take a while.</p><p lang="en" dir="ltr">Homers in MLB history that made the announcer say "The impossible has happened!":<br><br>1) Kirk Gibson<br>2) Bartolo Colon <a href="https://t.co/IKfzpPWp8A">https://t.co/IKfzpPWp8A</a></p><p>I didn’t really know what was going on. I thought I got traded or something.</p><p lang="en" dir="ltr">Goose Gossage must be sitting at home all sorts of mad because of how much pink these teams are wearing today.</p><p lang="en" dir="ltr">“That thing does not obey the laws of physics at all.” <a href="https://t.co/XyXLdfnbLU">pic.twitter.com/XyXLdfnbLU</a></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/sport/blog/2016/may/11/max-scherzer-mlb-strikeout-record-washington-nationals">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2016/may/11/jordan-spieth-players-championship-masters-sawgrass-danny-willett-rory-mcilroy-golf</link>
      <description>• ‘Danny Willett 100% earned his Masters win,’ says world No2<br />• Spieth and Willett join Rory McIlroy and Jason Day in Sawgrass field<p>Jordan Spieth does not attempt to hide the scale of his post-Masters trauma. “I wouldn’t wish that upon any of you,” the Texan said at Sawgrass on Wednesday, as he glanced back to an Augusta scene where he not only stumbled when a successful title defence was in his grasp, but also went through the painful ritual of handing the Green Jacket to Danny Willett.     <item>
      <title>UFC owners reportedly considering deal to sell organization for $4bn</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2016/may/11/ufc-sale-dana-white-fertitta-brothers</link>
      <description><ul><li>ESPN says Chinese company among frontrunners to buy organization</li><li>President Dana White has previously said UFC not for sale</li></ul><p>The owners of the UFC may be close to selling the wildly-popular mixed martial arts organization for more than $3.5bn, <a href="http://espn.go.com/mma/story/_/id/15503004/ufc-owners-advanced-talks-sell-promotion">according to an ESPN report</a>.</p><p>Brothers Lorenzo and Frank Fertitta, who own 80% of the UFC, have been rumored to be interested in selling the UFC for some time. The report names WME/IMG, China Media Capital, the Blackstone Group and Dalian Wanda Group as bidders and suggests the price for the UFC could rise to as high as $4bn. It would be a massive profit for the Fertittas, and possibly part-owner Dana White, the organization’s president, should he choose to sell as well. The Fertittas and <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2016/mar/04/the-fight-game-reloaded-how-mma-conquered-world-ufc">White bought the UFC in 2001 for just $2m</a>.</p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2016/mar/04/the-fight-game-reloaded-how-mma-conquered-world-ufc">The fight game reloaded: how MMA and UFC conquered the world | Andy Bull</a> </p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/sport/blog/2016/apr/20/conor-mcgregor-retirement-ufc-200">Conor McGregor's 'retirement' tests the limits of the UFC's powers | Les Carpenter</a> </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2016/may/11/ufc-sale-dana-white-fertitta-brothers">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>The Players Championship may not be the fifth major but it is a PGA flagship | Ewan Murray</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/sport/blog/2016/may/11/players-championship-fifth-major-pga-flagship-golf</link>
      <description>The prize fund, the strength of field and the venue means the tournament at Sawgrass is a prime event of any season<p>There are 12 days of Christmas, seven dwarves and four major championships. It has always been thus and any gratuitous addition to golf’s major set doesn’t make sense.</p><p>The PGA Tour is routinely accused of attempting to latch their Players Championship on to one of their sport’s big four. The Players, for around 20 years now, has commonly been referred to in passing as “the fifth major”. The claim is unfair; in its annual media guide, the Tour states the four major championships in golf. In marketing material, there has been no attempt to latch upon any suggestion of a fifth.</p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2016/may/10/danny-willett-golf-masters-justin-rose-players-championship">Danny Willett back after only one round of golf since Masters triumph</a> </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/sport/blog/2016/may/11/players-championship-fifth-major-pga-flagship-golf">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Spurs creak as the great Tim Duncan finally appears to decline</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/sport/blog/2016/may/11/nba-playoffs-tim-duncan-san-antonio-spurs</link>
      <description><p>If this is it for Tim Duncan in the NBA playoffs, he won’t get to go for 60 in a meaningless game like Kobe Bryant did. It will just be over</p><p>The San Antonio Spurs are now just one game away from being eliminated in the second round of the NBA playoffs. But Tim Duncan already looks finished. </p><p>For years basketball fans debated when Duncan’s abilities would slip and he would fall from his place among the best in the game. The discussion ultimately was deemed futile. Year after year, on through his mid-30s and nearing 40, Duncan remained excellent. His minutes were reduced as a precaution, but his impact when on the court was as great as ever. The debate was was decided and shelved: The Big Fundamental would never decline. And so we went back to focusing on and celebrating flashier, more exciting players. Duncan would always be around, like death, taxes and Gregg Popovich glaring at reporters. </p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/sport/blog/2016/may/10/stephen-curry-unanimous-nba-mvp-golden-state-warriors">NBA MVP Stephen Curry isn't a 'system player' – he is the system</a> </p><p lang="en" dir="ltr">Come for the show of pure wizardry, stay for the billionaire struggling to process misfortune. <a href="https://t.co/vQwmSrVvQR">https://t.co/vQwmSrVvQR</a></p><p>Of course cake is not bread. Is this why Americans are fat? You confused cake with bread? - Steven Adams, Thunder center, <a href="https://twitter.com/HPbasketball/status/730068020450590723">on the issue of obesity in America</a> </p><p lang="en" dir="ltr">Seven feet of not giving a crap: The untold story &amp; hunger of Thunder center Steven Adams: <a href="https://t.co/tA8fRUsDeK">https://t.co/tA8fRUsDeK</a> <a href="https://t.co/5RiVaIxyrH">pic.twitter.com/5RiVaIxyrH</a></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/sport/blog/2016/may/11/nba-playoffs-tim-duncan-san-antonio-spurs">Continue reading...</a></description>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/sport/san-antonio-spurs">San Antonio Spurs</category>

      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/sport/nba">NBA</category>

      <media:content width="140" url="https://i.guim.co.uk/img/media/64711ce58bbfe5390ec5901dcc071bd9f9d8def4/0_115_2646_1588/2646.jpg?w=140&q=55&auto=format&usm=12&fit=max&s=9345a7649dcecbcce0b7cd23953f7d70">
        <media:credit scheme="urn:ebu">Photograph: Eric Gay/AP</media:credit>
      </media:content>

    <item>
      <title>Cle Kooiman, the indoor soccer star who became an unlikely hero in Mexico</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/may/11/cle-kooiman-indoor-soccer-usa-mexico</link>
      <description><p>The big white guy from southern California was deemed the wrong fit for the skilful, technical Mexican game. But he won over the sceptics, and earned a place on USA’s World Cup roster</p><p>Not many soccer players can say that landing in Mexico’s Ciudad de Juárez was the fulfillment of a childhood dream. But then Cle Kooiman was no ordinary soccer player.</p><p>When Kooiman arrived in Juárez in 1990, he found a sprawling border town of ne million people, most of whom were looking for work in the city’s growing manufacturing industries. These were the halcyon days before Juárez became a byword for murder and drugs, back when this working-class town in the middle of the Chihuahua Desert believed it could spark a nationwide economic recovery. Its ambitions made it the perfect fit for Kooiman, a southern California native with a surfer’s sunny vibe and a chip on his shoulder wide enough to span the Rio Grande.</p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/apr/19/alan-hinton-soccer-nasl-white-boots">Alan Hinton: the stylist in white boots who became America's Mr Soccer</a> </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/may/11/cle-kooiman-indoor-soccer-usa-mexico">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Royals prospect Raul Mondesi given 50-game suspension for using steroids</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2016/may/10/royals-prospect-raul-mondesi-steroid-suspension-50-games</link>
      <description><p>The penalty was announced Tuesday against the 20-year-old infielder, who is on Kansas City’s 40-man roster but had been optioned to Double-A</p><p><a href="http://espn.go.com/mlb/team/_/name/kc/kansas-city-royals">Kansas City Royals</a> prospect <a href="http://espn.go.com/mlb/player/_/id/2932/raul-mondesi">Raul Mondesi</a> has been suspended for 50 games for testing positive for clenbuterol, a banned steroid.</p><p>The penalty was announced Tuesday against the 20-year-old infielder, who is on Kansas City’s 40-man roster but had been optioned to Double-A.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2016/may/10/royals-prospect-raul-mondesi-steroid-suspension-50-games">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Las Vegas mayor confident Raiders will relocate: 'I know we will have a team'</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2016/may/10/oakland-raiders-las-vegas-mayor-confident-in-move</link>
      <description><ul><li>Carolyn Goodman says ‘Las Vegas is not getting played in this deal’<br></li><li>Owner Mark Davis has pledged $500m towards stadium construction<br></li></ul><p>Carolyn Goodman, the mayor of Las Vegas, is confident that the Oakland Raiders will move to her city – providing the prospective relocation is handled properly.</p><p>The Raiders inched closer to a move to Las Vegas last month, after owner Mark Davis met Nevada officials and pledged $500m towards the construction of a new $1.4bn, 65,000-seat domed stadium. He said the Raiders would give Las Vegas and the NFL “an offer they can’t refuse” and would turn “the Silver State into the Silver-and-Black State”.</p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/sport/2016/may/10/tom-brady-cookbook-200-dollars-tb12-nutrition-manual">Tom Brady's $200 cookbook ‘TB12 Nutrition Manual’ sells out on website</a> </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2016/may/10/oakland-raiders-las-vegas-mayor-confident-in-move">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Tom Brady's $200 cookbook ‘TB12 Nutrition Manual’ sells out on website</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2016/may/10/tom-brady-cookbook-200-dollars-tb12-nutrition-manual</link>
      <description><ul><li>Covers are ‘made from natural wood with a laser-etched TB12 logo’</li><li>Cookbook features ‘89 seasonally-inspired recipes’<br></li></ul><p>In a further sign that the modern world has gone to the dogs, it emerged on Tuesday that Tom Brady’s cookbook has sold out. Yes, that’s right, Tom Brady’s cookbook: an 89-recipe tome written by an NFL quarterback that costs $200. It’s proved to be a big hit – and further copies won’t be available for another month at least.</p><p>Brady’s snappily-titled “TB12 Nutrition Manual”, available for purchase on the Patriots QB’s personal website at an attractive $200 on the nose, is out of stock, so those of you itching to find out which of the freshest ingredients Tom loves to cook with will just have to wait a little longer.</p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/sport/2016/apr/25/tom-brady-deflategate-suspension-nfl-roger-goodell">The NFL and Tom Brady need to cut a deal and kill Deflategate for good | Les Carpenter</a> </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2016/may/10/tom-brady-cookbook-200-dollars-tb12-nutrition-manual">Continue reading...</a></description>
